PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the Government's decision a fortnight before the Cambodian election to provide additional forces to Cambodia, six combat helicopters and 100 troops, sandbags, barbed wire, first aid kits and other stores. Does this decision not confirm the seriously deteriorating position in Cambodia which the Minister, almost alone in the international community, has consistently denied? How can a free and fair election take place when there is fighting between the factions, attacks on UNTAC, murder of settlers, a collapsed economy, shocking law and order and a breakdown of normal administrative functions?

—It is precisely in order to ensure that a free and fair election can take place in Cambodia in two weeks' time that the Australian Government has responded to this request, coming from the United Nations, for the supply of some additional equipment which will be very important in achieving that objective. The security situation in Cambodia has manifestly become more tense in recent weeks. It has been a fragile situation for some time. It is now an increasingly dangerous situation but it is by no means a desperate situation.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is, on all available evidence, the Khmer Rouge are determined to destabilise the election; they are determined to reduce the areas which are available for the free operation of polling stations; and they are determined, by these and other means, to discredit the election outcome. There is no doubt that that has been a longstanding political objective and is now being accompanied by some physical measures to make that more of an attempted reality. But there is no basis for the assumption that the Khmer Rouge are either trying to destroy the electoral process altogether or are capable of achieving that particular outcome. One of the reasons that are ensuring that is so is the absolute determination of the international community to proceed with these elections in the present circumstances.

The question I would ask Senator Hill—because it is one that is appropriate for someone who has constantly been trying from the outset of this process to denigrate it, to talk it down, to overstate the problems that are associated with it—is: what are the alternatives? What were Senator Hill's alternatives in 1989 to the quadripartite proposal which he did not like because it would have involved Khmer Rouge participation in the government? What was his alternative to the peace plan in 1991 which had the enormously self-evident virtue of not only engaging all the parties in the commencement of that process but disengaging the external patrons from support of their respective clients, which support was crucial to the maintenance of a process which had some hope of bringing peace and stability to the country as a whole?

This is a long debate. It is one that we have been having on innumerable occasions. The only common theme in it is the constant disposition on the part of the Opposition, led by Senator Hill, to articulate the kind of anxiety, the kind of doom saying, the kind of despair, the kind of pessimism which will be, unless carefully watched, a self-fulfilling prophecy. It is absolutely in order to avoid that kind of outcome that we and the rest of the community are responding as we are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is interesting that the Minister comes in here today and says it has been a longstanding political goal of the Khmer Rouge to bring down a peace process which is supposed to be based on national reconciliation. Arising out of the Minister's answer, I ask: what other governments have been asked to provide what further equipment and what has been their response? What is the quick reaction force which one of our helicopters will be supporting? What is the planned protection for civilian election monitors that the Minister is sending to Cambodia? What is to be the role of Australian forces in Cambodia after 28 May?

—It is manifestly absurd to seek a response to those questions in one minute. Let me say that the UN request was made a few days ago to the United States, Japan and the ASEAN countries, as well as Australia, since those countries were thought capable of deploying the necessary equipment most rapidly. Of the responses we know to date, Malaysia has offered eight Nuri helicopters and crews and the United States has offered to supply a whole variety of stores and equipment as well as to transport the equipment and aircraft offered by other countries in the region. We are still awaiting advice on the responses of the other countries approached.

PARA.TAB: The precise operational deployment of these helicopters and crews has not as yet been determined but it does look likely that they will be, as widely reported in the press, in the north-west part of the country where there is a manifest need for a quick movement capacity, both to ensure the effective conduct of the election and, more particularly, to ensure the safety and security of both the civilian and the military personnel in that part of the country.

It is, of course, the case that the situation is dangerous—it is very difficult—but it also remains the case that the election can proceed and will proceed in May and, provided there is a little bit more confidence shown by the international community than Senator Hill seems capable of, that will happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the Senate of what progress has been made in securing increased international air services to the vitally important Asia-Pacific region?
—A dorothy dixer.

—Mr President, I have actually been doing a few other things. The Government's decision to enable additional Australian carriers, such as Ansett, to operate with the opportunity to expand their operations into key Asia-Pacific markets is going to be extremely beneficial to the Australian tourism industry and provide a very helpful boost to employment. In facilitating the access of additional Australian carriers, and also providing opportunities for growth for Qantas, successful bilateral agreements have now been negotiated with many major Asian and Pacific countries, with capacity increases as follows: a 70 per cent increase in capacity with Malaysia; a 40 per cent increase in capacity with Indonesia; a 50 per cent increase in capacity with Singapore; and a 40 per cent increase, very importantly, with Japan.

PARA.TAB: Most recently, I am also pleased to advise the Senate, Australia reached agreement with the Republic of Korea for significantly increased capacity with that country. This increase will see a doubling of available capacity in October this year and the ability for carriers of both countries to provide daily services by 1995. The significance of this agreement can be seen from the excellent traffic growth rates of over 35 per cent on the Australia-Korea route in recent years—

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—A 35 per cent increase in growth, with the prospects for very strong increased growth on that route. I note that, since its establishment on 1 July 1992, the International Air Services Commission has already allocated capacity for carriers to operate to Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, China, France and Germany.

PARA.TAB: I might pause there for a minute to say that I wish to acknowledge the tremendous job that Stuart Fowler did in establishing this new commission—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nice of you to give him credit.
—Senator Kemp is amazing! I wish to express my regret that, due to his unfortunate ill-health, he has had to depart from that position.

PARA.TAB: The major beneficiaries of these initiatives in Australia's international aviation policy will undoubtedly be Australian tourism and trade. These developments will help build on the continuing growth in total international passenger traffic in Australia, with nearly 9 1/2 million passengers travelling in the year ended January 1993. This represents an increase of almost nine per cent on the previous year, despite continuing international economic conditions. That is very strong growth for Australia. Inbound passenger traffic for the month of January 1993 of 515,100 was the highest monthly amount ever recorded. It is an outstanding result.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications and relates to the standing aside of Christine Goode pending the outcome of the inquiry into the responsibility of the department, but not the Minister, for the latest pay television fiasco.
—Not true, Senator.

—That is interesting. The Minister said yesterday that Ms Goode stood aside by mutual agreement. Was that action initiated by Ms Goode, as the Minister would seem to imply, or was it initiated by others?

—That is a particularly stupid question. I do not think that Senator Alston or any person either in this chamber or elsewhere is entitled to infer that a statement issued jointly by the divisional head of the broadcasting division of the Department of Transport and Communications and, by necessary implication, the head of the Department of Transport and Communications is dishonest unless he or she can provide some facts to the contrary. That statement was tabled in this Senate yesterday.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Not an argument this time.
—There is no argument; there should not be. The question was not whether anyone had made a dishonest statement, but simply—
—That is an argument. What is your point of order?
—Just a moment. The question was not whether a dishonest statement had been made but simply who initiated the request. I simply ask that the Minister answer that question.
—That is a supplementary question. Now sit down.
—No, it is not.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I cannot believe that Senator Alston was ever a lawyer.
—Order! Senator Collins, I ask you to answer the question.
—The statement that I tabled in the chamber from—
—Who initiated it?

—Senator Macdonald should let me finish. Senator Alston clearly has not fully read the statement which I issued, and I think that is a disgrace. Senator Alston should read it. It clearly indicates that Ms Goode initiated the action.

PARA.TAB: I have looked at the press statements issued by Senator Alston, who has been crying crocodile tears about not pre-empting inquiries and `protecting the rights of public servants through natural justice'. He is now asserting here, by necessary inference, that that statement is untrue. He should read it; it nails down who did initiate this. Ms Goode has said in a statement, which I tabled in the Senate yesterday, that she did. That is the answer to the question. Senator Alston has not said it.

The other astonishing thing, I must say, is that Senator Alston, to my total surprise, shock and horror, said that I had said something defamatory about Ms Goode. It now turns out that the defamatory thing I said about Ms Goode is that she, as an officer, was suffering some stress. When did that kind of comment become defamatory? A whole stack of senior officers in that department are suffering a lot of stress at the moment. I have a head of a department who is suffering a lot of stress at the moment.

Stress is not gender specific. I am suffering from a lot of stress. Considering what I have to do at the moment, the only opportunity I get during the day to relieve that stress is by coming in here for Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I hope the Minister is up to it. The statement, which is unsigned by Christine Goode, attached to the secretary's statement says, `I elected to stand aside'. The question was: who initiated the process? Was any kind of preliminary inquiry held to determine which officers would need to stand aside in order for an inquiry to be carried out? Why did the Minister have his spokesman go around the gallery last week telling people, including people from the Canberra Times, that Ms Goode had been stood down for health reasons when clearly—
—Rubbish.
—Does the Minister deny that? Now he is saying that it was by mutual agreement and that she tapped the mat first. I ask the Minister: who initiated that process?

—I spoke in this chamber yesterday because of a statement that appeared on the front page of the Australian newspaper last Friday. Honourable senators should have a look at it—in fact, look at it and compare it to what Senator Alston said here in the chamber yesterday. On the front page of the Australian newspaper last Friday was a statement quoting Senator Alston and, if it was reported correctly, saying something that was absolutely untrue, that is, `that I had told him' that Christine Goode `had been stood down'.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Surely a Minister cannot get up and say there is a quote in an article when there isn't.
—Order! That is not a point of order. There are ways that that can be raised later.
—The cold hard facts are—and the public record shows it—that last week Senator Bourne learned her lesson about having meetings with Senator Alston and so did I.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Yesterday, I hosted a large delegation of representatives of pensioner and retired persons organisations. They raised the issue of the integration of Concord Repatriation General Hospital into the New South Wales health system, which will occur in seven weeks' time. What steps are being taken to ensure that high quality patient care for veterans will continue after the transfer of the Concord Repatriation General Hospital?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —I was able to address the delegation that Senator Childs referred to for a short time, but I know that a range of other issues were raised after I had to leave and come to the chamber to listen to that lot opposite.

PARA.TAB: I want to indicate, as Senator Childs knows, that the Concord Repatriation General Hospital will be integrated into the New South Wales public health system on 1 July of this year. After transfer, the Repatriation Commission will continue to be responsible for veterans' health care and the repatriation private patients scheme will be introduced. This scheme will protect the interests of over 120,000 veterans and war widows in New South Wales who currently receive repatriation health care.

The repatriation private patients scheme has been designed to shape health care to the changing needs of an ageing veteran community. The scheme will not only maintain the current level and range of services but, I believe, also bring a range of significant improvements. Benefits will include easier access to local hospitals; veterans and war widows will be treated as private patients; they will have more choices; and I believe they will have better options, including greater choice of specialists. It will mean that veterans and war widows can be treated locally instead of having to travel to Concord from all over New South Wales. The majority of veterans have indicated that local treatment is more convenient to them and their friends and families.

After 1 July, these veterans will have the choice of admission to a local public hospital as private patients without the need of prior approval from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The repatriation private patients scheme will ensure that veterans will also have access to a network of private hospitals and day surgery centres if no public hospital can treat them within a reasonable time. I want to emphasise—and this was raised by members of the delegation—that veterans and war widows who want to continue receiving their treatment at Concord can still do so.

Concord is the second repatriation hospital to be integrated into the State health system. Hobart Repatriation General Hospital was transferred to the Tasmanian Government 10 months ago, and I think the new system there is working well. Since integration there has been an increase in the number of veterans who are being treated locally. I acknowledge the support and the cooperation of the ex-service community in bringing about these major changes.

Our consultative mechanism includes the treatment monitoring committees, which will help ensure that the introduction of the repatriation private patients scheme occurs as smoothly as possible. The RSL, the War Widows Guild of Australia, the Veterans' Defence Services Council, TPIs, Legacy and the Regular Defence Forces Welfare Association are all represented on the treatment monitoring committees at both a State and a national level.

I am aware that some veterans in New South Wales may be nervous about the changes, but next month the Department of Veterans' Affairs will mail information packages to every entitled veteran and war widow in New South Wales to help them understand the new scheme. I believe the introduction of the repatriation private patients benefits scheme reflects the Government's continuing commitment to a high quality of treatment services which meet the changing needs of veterans and war widows as they grow older.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Indonesia, led by the Deputy Speaker of the Parliament, Dr John Ario Katili. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and I trust that your visit to Australia is both enjoyable and informative.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Minister dodged this one yesterday, so I will try again in a different way. Why does this Government not face up to the reality that it cannot afford its promised tax cuts, just as President Clinton did? Why does it not abandon them, or at the very least defer them, in the interest of the Budget deficit reduction? Is it not really likely that the Government will defer the 1 July 1994 cuts until January 1996, which will conveniently coincide with the next Federal election?
—No, it is not at all likely.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the recent progress that has been made towards multi-party elections in South Africa. What is the Government's attitude to the lifting of those economic sanctions that are still in place against South Africa? What proposals has the Australian Government developed to assist Australian business firms to invest in and to trade with South Africa once those sanctions are no longer in place?

—The Australian Government remains wholly committed to the phased lifting of sanctions against South Africa, as was agreed by Commonwealth heads of government in Harare in 1991, whereby trade and investment sanctions will be lifted as soon as agreement is reached on appropriate transitional mechanisms, and financial sanctions will be lifted once the recommendation is made by agreement at the multi-party forum or by an interim government. We will certainly move very quickly to lift sanctions as soon as sufficient progress is made in negotiations to enable those conditions to be met.

PARA.TAB: I am presently actively considering the questions of timing involved here with my Commonwealth ministerial colleagues. It is not at all impossible, on present rates of progress, that sanctions could be lifted sometime within the next few weeks, and indeed on all fronts simultaneously so far as trade, investment and financial sanctions are concerned.

It is the case that progress in negotiations in recent weeks has been very heartening, notwithstanding the obvious traumas associated with the assassination of Chris Hani; the death of the ANC's enormously respected former President in exile, Oliver Tambo; and also the continuing problems of reconciling the Inkatha Freedom Party and other more marginal organisations to principles that are essentially now agreed by the ANC and the South African Government. Notwithstanding those problems and difficulties, the process is moving forward.

The Government has recognised the need for Australian business to be ready to make the most of trade and investment possibilities in South Africa when sanctions are lifted. In June last year I advised the Australian-Southern African Business Council and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry that the Government had no objection to individual business representatives or business missions visiting South Africa on an exploratory basis to assess prospects for future involvement there.

While it will not be possible to provide active government assistance until sanctions are lifted, we already provide business inquirers with factual economic and other relevant information to help them assess future possibilities in South Africa. For example, my department will shortly be publishing a country economic brief on South Africa for the information of the Australian business community. Our embassy in South Africa can also provide similar background information.

Senator Cook recently gave approval for Austrade's trade commissioner in Nairobi to undertake a program of short-term visits to South Africa from May this year until sanctions are lifted, the purpose being to maintain a watching brief on developments in the South African economy to assess their implications for Austrade's support strategies for Australian firms and organisations once Austrade is in a position to again offer facilitation services. The first such visit will take place from 14 to 25 May.

Austrade has developed a contingency strategy for implementation when sanctions are lifted. It comprises the development of a market report on South Africa, the likely opening of an office in Johannesburg, a seminar program, a trade mission and a hotline to answer inquiries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. How can the Minister justify claiming that the inquiry into the pay TV tendering process is independent when today's print media claim that the terms of reference were drawn up by the secretary to the department being investigated? Is this so? If it is, why did the Minister mislead the Senate yesterday by saying that the terms of reference had been drawn up by the independent inquirer, Professor Dennis Pearce? How can the Minister claim that this inquiry will clear up the matter when it does not address the vital question of whether the Minister duly fulfilled his ministerial responsibility in signing a document without reading it?

—I was going to table this later in Question Time, but I will do it now. I table the letter from the secretary to my department to me, which outlines the terms of reference, and my reply, which makes the situation clear.
—How does that answer the question?
—Read it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister please, as well as tabling those documents, table the `pinks' of his answer to Senator McKiernan's question in Question Time yesterday?
—I know that Senator Chapman has been here only a short time, but they are available from Hansard.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science. Given the need to strengthen industry's competitive position, what can the Minister say about the significance of the cooperative research centres program in raising the level of business innovation? Does the Government's decision to expand the program by a further 10 centres indicate a growing commitment by industry to the program and a recognition of its commercial relevance?

—The Government is very proud of the success of the cooperative research centres program, as Senator McKiernan outlined in his question. The innovation that is coming with it, the involvement of small business, has been very successful and is getting more successful as the program further expands.

PARA.TAB: We have already established 52 cooperative research centres, involving already a Commonwealth commitment of nearly $100 million a year. Over the seven-year period, the Commonwealth commitment, the private sector commitment and that of other institutions totals nearly $2 1/2 billion.

The program was so successful that in his election speech the Prime Minister promised to establish a further 10 cooperative research centres. Expressions of interest have been called for already and the centres will be announced in the middle of next year. In calling for expressions of interest, we have emphasised that we want commercial involvement and commercial investment in those centres and we are hoping to meet a target of around 30 per cent commercial involvement.

We are particularly interested in getting the involvement in these centres of small and medium sized businesses, as identified in the now famous McKinsey report for the Australian Manufacturing Council, and in getting them to take up some of the excellent research and innovation that the centres have developed. The activities of the centres range from things such as information technology and molecular engineering to, as in my own State of course, advanced wine production. The centres carry out a very broad range of activities and we hope the further 10 centres will further broaden the range of research and industrial cooperation.

Already the centres have attracted international attention and have been well publicised in Australia. Recently the ABC program Quantum featured the CRC's eye research and technology. A special lens has been developed for sale in the Asian market, and three different private lens manufacturers have now come together to promote the sale of this new lens which is especially suitable for the Asian market.

We believe that the cooperative research centres program, which was developed as a result of the Prime Minister's science statement in 1989, has been an outstanding success, particularly in bringing together the science community, the government sector and, above all else, the private sector and involving them in improving Australia's innovation and adapting to applications in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister confirm that the terms of reference for the inquiry into the tendering processes for the pay TV licences do not require it to deal with the knowledge or actions of the Minister or his office in relation to the signing of the 19 January determination? In these circumstances, will the Minister explain what advice he or his office received on the matter in the lead-up to 19 January?

—As I said yesterday, if any Minister receives advice, then that advice is generated in the Minister's department. Officers do not write it in the park down the road and not keep a record of it. I can tell honourable senators that a bureaucrat produces a piece of paper when he blows his nose; a bureaucrat produces a piece of paper when one picks up a telephone and rings him. The records are one thing that this inquiry will lay out—and it will all be laid out. Every time something happens, a piece of paper is produced. I can assure honourable senators that bureaucrats are very good at producing pieces of paper.

PARA.TAB: In my experience in the relatively short time I have been a Minister, any meeting as a Minister that I have had with the bureaucracy, even to give oral advice, is always preceded—and I must say it is a very effective system; it works—by a written brief providing the issues that will be canvassed at the meeting and laying them out. So any advice that was given to me—and I do not know what is sitting over there in the department at all—will be revealed. I know what comes to my end; that is what I am saying.

What I know from three years as a Minister is that written advice to me will be in the department, and any substantive meetings where oral advice was given to me would also always be preceded by an issues paper. That is the only way, in the time one has available, that one can sensibly set up an agenda for a meeting. The issues are first canvassed on paper. So even if it were an oral briefing, there will be a piece of paper in the department that was sent over prior to that briefing indicating the issues that will be canvassed and their background. So the inquiry will reveal that completely.

Further to that—and I told the Senate this yesterday, and obviously the honourable senator did not hear me—I have already indicated to the secretary to my department that I personally, and every single member of my staff, will be available to give Professor Pearce all the cooperation that he wants, if he feels that it is appropriate to do so. We will speak to him and answer any questions that he has to put to us.

In going down this road, I would ask Senator Alston to come straight out and say it. I would like to find any person who would impugn either the professional qualifications or the personal integrity of Professor Dennis Pearce. I do not know him very well at all, but I know him by reputation. If Senator Alston is saying that he doubts Professor Pearce's ability to conduct this investigation, I know that Professor Pearce, being the lawyer that he is, would never have agreed to a set of terms of reference with which he was not happy. He will conduct this with integrity.

Senator Alston should come out and say what his major problem really is. His major problem really is not only that he is still in opposition but, having shifted his electoral office into the Melbourne Ports electorate to spearhead the Opposition attack on Clyde Holding, he knows that the result was that Clyde Holding put another 5 1/2 per cent on the vote; that is Senator Alston's real problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. I refer to the advertisement in the Australian on Saturday, 1 May regarding the second round of playing Australia grants. Would the Minister inform the Senate as to what Playing Australia is, the nature of the grants it administers and the benefits it provides to the community?

—The so-called playing Australia program, the touring program for the performing arts, is central to one of the key philosophical principles underlining the Government's arts policy and the initiatives outlined in the election. It is about increasing access in two ways: firstly, to give people who live outside the major capital cities access to the major performing arts organisations in Australia; and, secondly, to enable organisations which have their origins in the smaller States and cities—for example, the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra in Tasmania—to tour elsewhere and get access to greater audiences. This is very important. Senator Aulich correctly says that the second round of grants has just been called for in an advertisement on 1 May, applications for which close on 2 July.

PARA.TAB: Many Australians, as I am sure Senator Boswell and his National Party colleagues would be aware, who live outside the major capital cities have in the past missed out on the opportunity to see major performing arts organisations to which their taxes make significant contributions. We are seeking to make sure that those individuals have an enhanced—I do not think that we can provide equal, but an enhanced—opportunity to have access to those sorts of organisations, such as two major performing arts companies in Western Australia which are travelling throughout the other States.

A budget of $2 million for 1992-93 has given funding to assist more than 50 tours to all States and Territories. In view of the success of Playing Australia in its first year, not only will it be continuing but also, in the election, the Government committed itself to a similar touring scheme for the visual arts which will allow museums, galleries and libraries to tour. It will also assist regional libraries to host exhibitions in keeping with the principle of enhancing access for individuals, companies and performing artists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am sorry to bring arts into this place rather than talk about economics but, if we could all be a bit tolerant, I would ask whether the Minister would supply some detail about the diversity of tours which will be provided by Playing Australia in the first round of funding.

—Senator Aulich will be pleased to know that in 1993 there will be 12 tours to Tasmania; 16 to New South Wales; 14 to Queensland and the Northern Territory; 13 to Western Australia and Victoria; and 15 to South Australia. There will also be tours of companies originating from every State and Territory. Playing Australia is of enhanced value to artists from every State and Territory and to audiences in every State and Territory.

PARA.TAB: The biggest grant is going to Bran Nue Dae, the play developed in Broome, Western Australia, by the Black Swan Theatre Company, which will be touring remote and metropolitan centres in Queensland, South Australia, the Northern Territory and Victoria. Its talents may be wasted on some here, but I am sure it will be a very successful tour.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications, who appears to be communicating on the phone at the moment. Would the Minister like to finish his telephone conversation and I will ask him a question?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is it not a deliberate insult to the Senate for a Minister to deliberately sit there and treat the Senate in that way?
—Order! I call Senator Kemp.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the department's advice on the extent to which microwave technology might be used for pay TV. The Minister will be aware of the famous note for file by Mr Beale regarding his conversation with Mr Keating on 27 January. Does the Minister agree with Mr Keating that Cabinet, and I quote from the report of Mr Beale's note for file, had been `notoriously misled on this issue'? If the Minister agrees with Mr Keating's view, can he indicate the officers who were involved in the preparation of this notoriously misleading advice?

—Again, it would be good if those honourable senators who criticise people for not reading the paper would read the paper. I tabled the advice to Cabinet yesterday. It has `Cabinet in confidence' on it. That sort of stuff is normally not tabled, but it has been made available in the court processes, everybody has read it and I tabled it. Honourable senators will see from that advice that it lays out, page after page, in the problems associated with MDS. I did not disagree with any of those technical matters that Mr North raised when that paper was given to Cabinet, and I do not now. It makes as much sense to me now as it made to me then that no sensible person would put enormous capital into MDS for a country the size of ours. The Senate assumed that. That is the point the honourable senator is forgetting. The Senate made that assumption.
—Absolute rubbish.
—Senator Alston jumps in again and says, `Absolute rubbish'. He should have a look at the statements made by the then shadow Minister for communications, Warwick Smith. They are half an inch deep.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on the question of relevance. My question was whether Senator Collins agreed with the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, that the department had given notoriously misleading advice on microwave technology and the extent to which it may be used for pay TV. Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister's view, or does he not? It is a simple question.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We have seen several examples today of false and bogus points of order. If Senator Kemp wishes to clarify any matter, he has the opportunity by way of supplementary questions. A point of order is to the Standing Orders of this chamber, not the first argument that enters the Senator's dense head.
—Order! The point of order was on relevance. I think the Minister was answering the question, but I ask him to be relevant.

—Mr President, I have not stepped from the path of relevance once. Warwick Smith—and I can call him Warwick Smith now because he is not a member of the other place—has not only made statements in the Hansard but also put out press statements supporting the Government's position and saying that MDS would be `a niche operator'. That was the understanding not just of the officers of the department but also of the entire Senate. Senator Schacht will confirm this. Obviously Senator Alston slept through the entire proceedings of the Senate committee on pay television. All of the advice that was given in that Cabinet submission—honourable senators should have a look at it—is technically correct. What we all made a misjudgment on was the marketplace. We all thought it would behave rationally; it behaved irrationally.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I ask you why, unless Senator Alston says that the Senate made a total fool of itself, this Senate—the Opposition and the Democrats—took the pay TV section out of the original Bill and put it off to a Senate committee. It was on the principal issue of the involvement of the ABC in having a structured role in a nationally delivered system of pay television. That Senate committee laboured long and hard for months and came back to the Senate with a report which put a whole stack of conditions on the satellite—the cross-media restrictions, industry conditions and a structured role for the ABC. It put none of those conditions on MDS, on the assumption—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—I know it is true. This guy is in outer space at the moment. The only people who doubted that advice—and I have to give them credit as I did give Senator Bourne credit publicly months ago for this—were the Democrats. They came to me during the debate and asked the Government to consider restricting MDS to narrowcast only. I did not agree with that advice because—
—You should have.

—No, I should not have, because we always anticipated, and still do, that a hybrid system could develop with a satellite delivered system being rebroadcast by MDS. People are now saying that this is something new that has suddenly popped up; honourable senators should look at the Hansard record of the debates and particularly at what I said. There are two regions of Australia which it will be difficult to access direct from the satellite; they are northern Australia and southern Australia.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We are having trouble getting a straight answer from Senator Collins to a straight question. Senator Collins should direct his mind to the question. Does the Minister agree with Mr Keating's description that his department gave notoriously misleading advice on the extent that microwave technology may be used for pay TV? If the Minister agrees with the Prime Minister, could the Minister name the officers who were responsible for giving this notoriously misleading advice?

—It is probably a good thing for the Australian community that the good Senator is in this place where he cannot do any harm. I have said to the Senate that there will be areas of Australia where MDS can be limited. I plead with Senator Bourne to agree with that advice now and not restrict MDS to narrowcasting only; just delay it until the satellite service starts to deliver that national system. If these amendments go through the Senate, that system originally intended—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Standing order 194 requires the Minister, once he begins to answer a question, to be relevant to the question asked. You have already directed him to be relevant. Would you further direct him and make him abide by your ruling?
—I think Senator Collins was asked a straightforward question and he should answer it.

—I am about to conclude in one sentence. Why would the Senate have put all that labour in and imposed all of those conditions on the satellite and none on MDS if we had not assumed that MDS would not be a threat to the viability of the satellite?

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that both the Federal Labor Government and the State Labor Government of South Australia began the MFP initiative with a promise that this project would be substantially privately funded? How long is it since the project was initiated? How much have the two governments now either spent or committed to the MFP? What firm commitment does the MFP have at this stage and from which private companies? What are the amounts involved and when will these commitments materialise?

—The MFP Development Corporation is a State statutory body, as I guess Senator Coulter would be aware, that is responsible to the South Australian Parliament for the management of the project on behalf of the Federal and State governments. While the concept was first discussed in 1987 the establishment legislation was only passed in April 1992 and the board had its first meeting in December last year and it has just appointed a CEO.

PARA.TAB: In June 1992 an agreement was signed between the Commonwealth and South Australia on their respective responsibilities on the MFP. The MFP against this background has to be seen as a long-term project. It will be developed over some 20 to 30 years. It is therefore really quite premature to criticise the level of private involvement that exists at the moment, as Senator Coulter's question implies. Nonetheless, the private sector is heavily involved in the project and this is expected to grow, and the board is certainly drawing heavily on private sector expertise.

A number of projects are being developed now with a view to private sector involvement in areas such as tele-medicine, international software training and media. The first commercial MFP project was announced last June involving the formation of a privately owned MFP services company to implement environmentally and commercially sustainable strategies for waste management, as well as provision of water, electricity and gas for the MFP site itself. Interest from the international business community is being managed through the MFP's international advisory board.

Finally, on the question of costs, the Commonwealth has committed up to $70 million, including a contribution to start-up costs, servicing for the international advisory board, support for MFP developments in other States, investigation into energy efficient utilities, support services for the MFP, the provision of 50 DAS staff to assist in research and development of the site and provision of building better cities funding for the core site. In addition, a wide range of Commonwealth programs have been identified as potentially providing support for the MFP. At the South Australian level, that government has established an enterprise zone for the MFP offering fast tracking of regulation and approval processes, concessional electricity and water charges and 10-year relief from taxes and charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Did a Commonwealth official suggest or apply pressure on the Commonwealth Bank of Australia to improve its profit performance and dividend distribution? What is the Minister's response to the decision by the bank to make 7,500 of its staff redundant when the bank is operating profitably? Could the Government please explain where is the poor performance of the bank or the lack of managerial judgment that warrants such retrenchments in recessionary conditions?

—I am very disappointed to see Senator Watson back in the second row; I thought he did well enough on the front row to get promoted. The Treasurer's advice in the only conversation which I have had with him about this matter made it clear that the decision with regard to staffing of the Commonwealth Bank was exclusively a decision for the board of that bank and that he had not intervened, either to persuade the board to do so or not to do so because, particularly since the float of some part of the bank, the responsibility of the board is to all the shareholders, not just the majority shareholder, the Commonwealth. Accordingly, the Treasurer had not intervened to interfere in the board's discharge of that particular obligation. I will refer Senator Watson's question to the Treasurer to see whether he wants to provide any further information.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Is it true that an Australian company has just landed a significant contract to supply aerospace technology to Taiwan? If so, what is the value of the contract and does this now position us in the international market for further contracts of this sort? What growth has there been in high-tech or sophisticated manufacturing exports out of Australia to countries in the Asian region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time, Senator Schacht answered a question about Australian science lending its skills to create lenses which are destined for export to the Asian market. That is a commendable initiative. There has been, however, an Australian company, Interscan International, which is a fully owned subsidiary of AWA, which has won a $5 million contract to supply three microwave landing systems to Taiwan. The contract is with the Taiwan civil aeronautics administration.

PARA.TAB: This is an important breakthrough and it is an important contract for Interscan which is now in the high-tech top end of the aeronautical industry within this region. In winning this contract, it beat several significant firms from the United States and from Europe. Given this contract, it is now in a very positive position to win other contracts within the Asia-Pacific region where there is fast growing demand for services of this sort. There are another 10 possible systems to come on stream in the next four or five years in Taiwan. Given the fact that Interscan won the initial contract, one would imagine that it would be in the box seat to win the others.

There are many people in government, in the Public Service and in private enterprise who worked together in order to win this contract. Indeed, Mr John Dougall, the chief executive of AWA, paid tribute to the Government and many others when he described this as a textbook example of the Government and the private sector working together to win a significant contract in the national interest.

ANSWER.PARA: The last part of Senator Jones's question is about other high-tech or sophisticated manufacturing exports out of Australia to countries in the Asian region. The classification is `elaborately transformed manufactures' and there are success stories in Australian exporting in this area all over the region. Over the last five years our export of elaborately transformed manufactures has increased some 23 per cent in north-east Asia and some 27 per cent in South East Asia. In money terms, the value of elaborately transformed manufactures comes to $1.9 billion for South East Asia and $4 billion for north Asia and South East Asia taken together, which has now overtaken North America and Europe as a major market for elaborately transformed manufactures.

I want to make one final comment about these significant exports. We still have a perceptional problem to overcome in the region. When countries in the fast growing economies, particularly of the ASEAN tigers, think of where they should look for high technology, they do not often think of Australia first; they think of Europe, North America or Japan. There is a lingering perception in the region that we are an exporter of agricultural products and mineral commodities only. That is a perception that we all have to work hard to turn around because the facts are, recorded on the bottom line of our trade accounts, that one of the fastest growing areas of our export output is elaborately transformed manufactures—high value added goods that take skill and learning to make. That is something that we have to change as a perception in this region so that more and more the significant growth that we have commenced burgeons further and achieves its full potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In the Shan Memorial Lecture given in Western Australia, an extract of which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on 16 August 1990, Professor Ross Garnaut, the newly appointed head of the Government's wool industry review committee, stated that in addition to removing all tariffs by the year 2000 it would be appropriate to remove anti-dumping arrangements as well. Given the disastrous consequence to many rural industries which would follow such a move, and given this Government's commitment to an effective anti-dumping regime to prevent a flood of subsidised imports stealing markets from our efficient producers, what confidence can the wool industry and the Government have that Professor Garnaut will not propose a similarly unworkable and industry threatening solution for the wool industry?

—The Government is committed to an effective anti-dumping regime, as Senator Boswell has said, taking into account the necessity that that be a credible regime in terms of international trade rules and the larger trade objectives that we are trying to achieve. Professor Garnaut is acutely well aware of the parameters of government policy within which he is operating in the conduct of this inquiry, and I am sure he will take that into account in any recommendations he and his colleagues put together.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Government ensure that, following the review, its wool industry policy will be in line with the needs of the wool industry, as expressed by its leaders, rather than in line with the economic dogmas peddled by Professor Garnaut, who is well known as the pied piper of the economic rationalists?

—I have to say that some of the leaders in the wool industry have not performed all that spectacularly over the last few years in getting the policy parameters right in terms of the present and future conduct of the industry. That is one of the things to be taken into account in this really quite fundamental review of wool industry arrangements that is now under way. Professor Garnaut is an outstanding economist who has the full confidence of the Government in this respect, but his recommendations, such as they prove to be, will be considered by the Government on their merits and consistent with the other dimensions of government policy.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the recent introduction of the seventh tanker to the liquefied natural gas trade from the North-West Shelf project in Western Australia to Japan. I ask the Minister: how have the Government's shipping reforms contributed to Australia's involvement in this very significant trade?

—I was as pleased to see the delivery of this tanker as, possibly, the Treasurer was not, in terms of the balance of payments. But the delivery of the tanker Northwest Sandpiper earlier this year to her Australian operators symbolises the achievement of Australia's massive shipping reforms. This is the seventh specialised LNG tanker to join the fleet servicing the North-West Shelf gas project and the third to be Australian flagged and crewed.

PARA.TAB: The construction of an eighth LNG tanker, Northwest Stormpetrel, has now commenced in Japan. This will be required to boost LNG deliveries to Japan to seven million tonnes a year by 1995. The Northwest Stormpetrel will be the fourth Australian flagged ship in the eventual eight-ship fleet. Two of the other four ships sail under the United Kingdom flag and two fly the Japanese flag.

The reason that I say this is a significant achievement and demonstration of the success of Australia's shipping reform is that the decision by the North-West Shelf joint venture to have these Australian flagged vessels was made on a purely commercial basis. The upgraded training and multiskilling, which are vital aspects of the shipping reform program, complemented by specialised company training have been instrumental in the Northwest Sandpiper being introduced with a crew of 22. The two earlier Australian crewed tankers currently operate with crews of 24, but they will also be reduced to 22 as scheduling permits. For those who are fond of making international comparisons, this contrasts with their Japanese and British sister ships, which have complements of 27 and 29 respectively.

The three Australian flagged vessels currently in operation will carry 37 per cent of Australia's LNG export cargoes valued at $400 million. Freight earnings of $78 million will remain in Australia. The Government recently announced a further reform program to enhance the efficiency and competitiveness of the Australian shipping fleet. Despite pay television, I have only just had a meeting with some of the major representatives of shipping interests in Australia to ensure that that further round of reform takes place and is as successful as the last round.

Shipping reform has already encouraged significant investment in new, modern tonnage, with 32 vessels joining the Australian fleet since 1987. It has been the biggest capital investment in new shipping in Australia in this country's history and would never have happened without the success of the reform program. There has also been an unprecedented improvement in the industrial relations environment in the shipping industry. Australian seafarers and ship management are proving that, given a fair chance, their skills and reliability are world class.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—by leave—I cannot make a plea on behalf of another, so I will speak for myself. I have now had an opportunity to read at some length the remarks made by Senator Collins yesterday, and I think it necessary for me to deal with them in all their manifest inaccuracy.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, Senator Collins said that the Australian Financial Review had written stories about Christine Goode being forced to stand aside and that that, therefore, could only have derived from a discussion that I had with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the front page of the Australian.

—We will come to that in a moment. As anyone would know, the fact is that journalists are not required to run the government line. If a government wants to say that someone has chosen to resign when everyone knows that that person got the chop—had a gun held at his or her head and was told, `Unless you offer to resign we will sack you'—I would not have thought it improper for the press to write that that person was forced to resign. Therefore, to suggest that, because the Australian Financial Review wrote a story stating that Ms Goode had been forced to stand aside, it must have been based on information conveyed by me is demonstrably and self-evidently inaccurate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins then went on to talk about the meeting that took place—if we could call it a meeting—between Senator Kernot, Senator Collins and me. I want to explain the circumstances that surrounded that meeting because I think it is important, particularly when one has regard to the fact that yesterday the AAP actually ran a story, whether it came from the Minister's office or not I do not know, suggesting that this was a meeting arranged by the Minister with some of his departmental officers, together with Senator Kernot and me.

The facts of the matter are that Senator Kernot and I were walking outside this chamber having a discussion about superannuation when Senator Collins waddled over, did his usual trick and took over the conversation. He insisted that he had some important things to say. He then rabbited on for about 20 minutes, by which time I had had enough and I suspect Senator Kernot had had enough as well. We eventually had to say to him that we had to leave.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty minutes; ten!
—It was 20 minutes.
—What do you think it was?
—You must be running out of things of substance to say.
—There you go again. An example—
—Order! Senator Alston and Senator Collins have conducted a debate across the chamber for three days, and I would rather it come through the Chair.

—I defer to the Chair. In these circumstances it ought to be a matter of priority for all senators to do their very best to get the facts right. For instance, in that last example Senator Collins immediately rubbished the proposition that it was anything like 20 minutes, heard Senator Kernot say it was and then tried to change the subject. That is a very good example of how he will say or do—
—It was more like 10 minutes.
—Do you want to concede it was 20 or not?
—So what!

—That is precisely the point; change the subject. I will come back to that meeting because it is important. That meeting, if we can call it that, I think took place for what seemed like hours but it was probably only 20 minutes and I hardly got a word in edgeways except to try to persuade—
—It was an infamous meeting, however long.

—That is true, but whether it was a voluntary or involuntary meeting is another matter. In the course of that meeting there were certainly things said that I regard as highly defamatory of another. For Senator Collins to say in this chamber today that merely to suggest that someone was under stress was highly defamatory, again either shows that he did not know what he was saying at the time or he has forgotten. I am not going to elaborate in public, but I simply say—
—You will leave the smear in the air.
—No, no. If the Minister wants me to tell him, I will. I thought it was over the top, and I want it to be clear that I did not make that comment to anyone.

PARA.TAB: Following that meeting the Minister then went on to say, `I went out and got on the telephone and rang a whole swag of journalists in the press gallery, three of whom rang my office to check the story'. These are the facts, Mr President. That meeting finished at about 11.30 a.m. I did not ring any journalists. I came into the chamber to hear Senator Collins announce that he had decided that the inquiry would be chaired by someone outside the department; someone with legal and administrative experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was suggested by Senator Kernot, and I said, `Good suggestion'.
—That is preposterous. The Minister argued long and hard against that.
—I said, to the best of my recollection, `That is a good idea. I will think about it'.

—The Minister was consistently saying that the head of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services was the appropriate person to chair it. I suggested that it be someone from outside, like a retired judge, and Senator Collins would not have a bar of it. But the point is that I did not ring any journalists at that time. I left Question Time halfway through and I went to Melbourne. I was in a meeting for some hours. I was called out of a meeting by a staff member, told that a number of journalists had rung and I asked whether I would ring them back.

PARA.TAB: When I rang them back, each of them asked me whether I knew that Christine Goode had resigned. I said to one journalist, `I am not surprised'. Indeed, I think I was asked whether I was surprised, and I said that I was not surprised because Senator Collins had indicated that that was likely earlier in the day. That comment found its way on to the front page of the Australian; not in quotation marks, as Senator Collins tried to suggest today, once again, apparently not knowing the difference between direct and indirect speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying they misquoted you?

—I am telling you the facts. One journalist asked me whether I had heard that others were going as well. I said, `No, I have not heard that'. So, once again, for Senator Collins to say that I told journalists that heads were rolling in the department and that there was a political witch-hunt is absolute and total fabrication. I do not know where he got it from. All I know is that his press officers, who seem to have a great knack for getting the gallery offside, were out there planting this story about health reasons when Senator Collins was in here saying that it was simply a decision by mutual consent to stand aside.

PARA.TAB: I do not know why these background stories are passed out—presumably they are intended to diminish Senator Collins's political opponents. All I can say is that they do him no credit. Whether or not he is a failed law student is no justification for wanting to sully people's reputations. I do not expect an apology from him. Despite yesterday, when I thought—game, set and match—he made it clear that he accepted that I did not have the document and that I therefore could not have deliberately withheld it, he thrice refused to back down from that position. All I can say is: would he please repeat those remarks outside the chamber?

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I will not detain the Senate very long. Frankly, I think it is about time that this whole matter was dropped, because it is ridiculous for an opposition that says it is concerned about the central policy issue of pay television to have now been running on this for three days. I would never have even entered into the debate if it had not been for the statement carried on the front page of the Australian last Friday quoting Senator Alston quoting me. If Senator Alston now wants to say that the Australian quote is inaccurate, let him do so.

PARA.TAB: I invite honourable senators to look at the record. Last week Senator Alston met—and the only thing I know about this meeting is what I saw in the press, both on television and in the newspaper—with Senator Bourne of the Australian Democrats to discuss setting up a Senate inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I am loath to intrude, but as I understand it the Minister has sought leave to make a personal explanation.
—I can say anything I like.
—So he is just at large once again to vilify and defame anyone on any basis.
—He sought leave to make a short statement.
—I am not as large as I was; look at this. Considering that I use food as a crutch, I am not doing too badly at the moment—still down to one lettuce leaf a day.
—How much have you lost, Bob?

—Seventeen kilos. That will be the story for today. Senator Alston met with Senator Bourne last week for a couple of minutes to talk about a Senate inquiry. Senator Alston went out, told the press gallery—and it was published—that the Democrats had just agreed to support the Opposition's call for a Senate inquiry. I noticed that—I paid some attention to it—and said, `Oh'.

PARA.TAB: What then happened was that Senator Bourne, and on television it looked to me like a very angry Senator Bourne, went public and said that that was absolute rubbish and that in fact all she had said to Senator Alston—and I have no reason to disbelieve her—was `show me the terms of reference and we'll have a look at them'. All I said before, as I said this morning, is that Senator Bourne clearly learnt her lesson last week about having meetings with Senator Alston, and I learnt mine.

In respect of the Australian Financial Review—and this will be the last word I have to say on the subject—I always make a distinction, and always have done, between news columns and opinion columns in newspapers. I meant what I said this morning. If a journalist wants to disagree with me about this, he or she can. Journalists are very happy—and entitled—to talk about the standards of competence that Ministers should obey, so I am sure it is perfectly appropriate for me to canvass for one minute what I think a journalist's professional ethics are.

High up on the list of crimes against the AJA code of ethics in my view is misreporting the news; that is, going to a demonstration, seeing 100 people there and reporting it as a thousand. But a worse crime than that in my view—and it always has been—is censorship of the news; that is, distorting the news by omission.

One can say what one likes in opinion columns. For years I have had a high regard for the Australian Financial Review. I have publicly said that in my view the Australian Financial Review has carried the best and the most comprehensive account ever of the entire Coronation Hill debate. I have also kept a complete chronological clipping file of the uranium debate, because the Australian Financial Review gave the best coverage of that.

I am saying that if two officers issue a statement of news fact that this was by agreement, then no journalist in a news column is entitled to print that it was anything other than that, unless that person can demonstrate it was not. Journalists can speculate in opinion columns about that as long as they like, but they are not entitled to leave that out, and that is what they did.

The Australian Financial Review article contained 1,500 words. The only paragraph they did not print was the one containing the words `by mutual agreement'. Every other paper in the country carried that, despite opinion columns that asserted to the contrary, and they are entitled to do that. For example, the opening paragraph of the article in the Canberra Times stated that Christine Goode `has stood aside'. This was not the case with the Australian Financial Review. In that particular story—and I am confining my remarks to that particular story—the operative words, `by mutual agreement', in the statement were ignored and left out.

I would like to know when the Australian Financial Review stopped being a newspaper of record. That is what I would like to know in respect of that particular story. Until the Australian Financial Review proved with investigative reporting or whatever that those words were not true, it should at least have printed them and acknowledged them. That was my complaint about the Australian Financial Review, and I stand by it.

I have to say this: if some of the journalists that comment in columns on the professional ethics of politicians, and suggest that they resign, applied so carelessly, frivolously, pompously and condescendingly the words `He is intelligent and he is nice but he should go'—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. We gave leave to Senator Collins to make a short statement. He has now been speaking for eight minutes and what he has said is all rubbish. It is not of any interest to the Senate whatsoever and we do have important business to carry on with.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr President, I will conclude. If those journalists applied even half the same standards of professional competence to themselves as they so carelessly do to others, they would resign tomorrow and should resign tomorrow as a result of that story. This has been—and I will conclude on this note—a demonstration of irrelevance. Senator Alston has been carrying this all week as the major issue for the simple reason that he has nothing else to offer.

SPEECH.PARA: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1992-93

In Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1992-93, appropriations totalling $5.2 million additional to those made in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1992-93 are sought for recurrent expenditures of the Parliamentary Departments. The increase sought relates primarily to essential and unavoidable costs associated with activities of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 6) 1992-93

In Appropriation Bill (No. 6) 1992-93, appropriations totalling $418.4 million—additional to those made by Appropriation Acts (Nos. 2 and 4) 1992-93—are sought for Capital Works and services, payments to or for the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, advances and loans, and for other services. The proposed appropriations are needed to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures for which provision was not made in those Acts.

The additional appropriations are sought to meet certain cost and price increases which have occurred since the Budget, together with other commitments that have been made by the Government. Areas where significant increases are sought over amounts provided in Appropriation Acts (Nos. 2 and 4) 1992-93 include:
$12.3 million for an increase in the working capital advance to the Legal Services Trust Account in the Attorney-General's Department due to unanticipated delays in the billings cycle;
$7.0 million, out of a $44.6 million package, as support for specialist wool growers under the exceptional circumstances provisions of the Rural Adjustment Scheme;
$17.5 million for compensation to the States for the extension of fringe benefits to pensioners and long term allowees and beneficiaries;
$5.4 million for one-off funding for ABC television broadcasts to South East Asia; and
$263.0 million for a special assistance package to South Australia.
The remaining $113.2 million included in Appropriation Bill (No. 6) comprises minor increases in a number of programs for a range of portfolios.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1993-94

This Bill seeks interim appropriations for the ongoing requirements of the Parliamentary Departments up to 30 November 1993, by which date it is expected that the Budget Appropriation Bills will have been enacted. The Bill totals some $56.4 million which is $3.3 million, or 6.2 per cent, greater than the amount provided for in the Supply period 1992-93.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1993-94

This Bill seeks interim appropriations, totalling some $2,489 million, for expenditure on capital works and services, payments to or for the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, and certain other services up to 30 November 1993, by which date it is expected that the Budget Appropriation Bills will have been enacted.
The amount sought is $1547.7 million, or about 38.3 per cent, less than that provided in the Supply Act (No. 2) 1992-93.
Of the amount sought, about $275 million is as a consequence of new initiatives not previously included in the annual appropriation Bills.
The remainder represents payments associated with existing programs which have previously been approved by parliament, after taking into account the transfer of items from Bill 2 to Bill 1.
Major increases in existing subdivisions include:
Arts and Administrative Services
$50.2 million for Commonwealth office activity;
Finance
$25.1 million for increased provision for natural disaster relief and restoration;
Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services
$79.5 million relating to a revised agreement with the States on funding arrangements for disability programs;
Veterans' Affairs
$18.8 million for the transfer to the States of the Repatriation General Hospitals;
Social Security
$30.6 million for compensation for the States for the extension of fringe benefits;
Transport and Communications
$208.7 million for an equity contribution to Telstra; and
Treasury

$98.9 million for a special assistance package to South Australia and increased funding for Building Better Cities, partially offset by a reduction in assistance to the States for the redemption of debt.
In respect of new provisions which reflect new Government initiatives, these have been separately itemised in the Bill, in accordance with longstanding convention, and include:
Employment, Education and Training
$5.2 million for expenditure for Key Competency Measures for Schools;
$6.5 million for expenditure under Teacher Professional Development Programs;
Finance
$60.0 million for QANTAS flotation costs;
Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services
$5.7 million contribution towards immunisation against Haemophilus Type B disease;
Primary Industries and Energy
$12.0 million for a working capital advance for payment to the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service Trust Fund;
$30.0 million for a contribution to electricity grid infrastructure;

Payments to the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service Trust Account including $74.0 million for quarantine and inspection services, $20.3 million for community service obligations and $14.0 million for contingency funds; and
Transport and Communications
$15.0 million contribution to airport infrastructure improvements.
As I indicated when introducing the Supply Bill (No. 1), the provisions in this Bill do not anticipate decisions to be taken in the 1993-94 Budget context.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
